Those keys are out of date with respect to the signatures.  (Approx. 8 people in that list have signed my key.)  You'd have to retrieve the updated signatures from the public keyservers in order to get an accurate list.  We will not update the KEYS file everytime someone signs a key.

Once you get the keys, you know the ID number/fingerprint.  Doing an update on the keys will get you updated signatures.
creator: jerenkrantz@apache.org

text:
Sure, updating the file every time a key gets signed appears to be exaggerated,
but how about monthly?

Asking people to update the keys from (by far not always available) keyservers
looks to me rather like practical assigment in school than the service of a
leading open source project that prides itself to have mass-appeal....
creator: hauser@acm.org

text:
The reason to distribute the KEYS file at all is to know what keys are the 'right ones' rather than obtaining current signatories for the keys.  If you wish to obtain the current list of signatures for a key, you need to consult the public key server.

It is unreasonable to expect us to update the keys on a regular basis when people outside of our control may sign our keys and update the key servers without our intervention.  (Why they would do it without consulting us is beyond me, but we've had people sign all of our keys whom we don't know.)

We're providing the KEYS file as a mechanism for bootstrapping, but that only goes so far.
creator: jerenkrantz@apache.org

text:

But now that you say that on the public servers, there end up endorsing
signatures on your key building the possibility for a trust web you perhaps
perfer to be not part of, this is even more the reason that the KEYS should be
kept relatively up to date at the center once rather than having thousands of
people over and over downloading keys that are beyond your control and may
contain misleading facets...

text:
There are several issues mentioned in this bug, but I think that they are all
WONTFIX
1) I regenerated a KEYS file with all the updated signatures. This made the KEYS
file 500k rather than 150k. I think that people should simply --refresh-keys
rather than having to dowload a .5M keys file. Doing a refresh added about 2200
signatures.
2) I don't expect there's any way that we're going to add personal contact
information to the keys file. Email addresses are already contained in that
information, and seems sufficient. Nobody wants to have their phone numbers in
here, so that's not going to happen.
creator: rbowen@apache.org
